description:
Welcome to Chicago. Don’t smell the gunpowder in the air or the scent of perfume coming from the whorehouses or the aftershave of the mobsters hanging around the corner.

Stay alert, grab your bucks before your enemies beat you to it, build your gang fast and better than all the rest.  Because the next thing you smell could be the flowers on your grave.

The game is based by an innovative system of play called "confronts": each mobster, according to his skills to do an action, must confront the power of the Gang (coming from influence tokens) with all other powers in the same district.

Each of the players plays a Boss of a Gang on Chicago or the Police Chief at the beginning of the 1920. To rule the city, as Boss, you must command your mobsters as pawn to earn money coming from robbery, run clubs and assassinate enemies. If you represent the Law, instead, you must fight the crime with your policemen, closing the clubs, capturing mobsters and also try to send one of the Bosses to jail.

Kingdom is a game where players battle against each other trying to be the first to match “The Ideal Kingdom” which needs to be made of the right collection of cards. However, the right cards needed in this game may not be the right cards in another game. True, you may pull the same set of cards, but it is highly unlikely there are 531,441 different combinations. You could push ahead getting the right cards in the positions you need them to be in, or do you work to thwart other players efforts. Adding the change a winning combination of the ideal kingdom allows for changes in strategy from one game to the next. Each player starts with three cards and needs to work to create the “Ideal Kingdom” which is a combination of six cards. Each color of card has specific attacks, defense, and special action. Certain colors cards can only sit next to other certain color cards, and coming in contact with opposing cards leads to inactivity or removal. That has something to do with court politics. Cards are drawn and played in turn order, with actions being directed by the cards you have laid out in front of you. Some of those actions allow you to draw extra cards, look at another player’s cards, steal cards, or battle. But, your strategy has to be planned so you can create the ideal kingdom to win. There are 9 major game changer cards in the deck, like creating Immunity from the Black Plague, or Jesters that will play tricks and change the cards. This actually helps the player with the least amount of cards to actually come back and try to win.

You and your band of scallywag pirates are in deep, deep trouble. Something you’ve never seen before has been following your ship, seeking revenge, growing stronger with rage. Perhaps you took one treasure too many, and now fate is closing in. So hurry while the wind is brave in your sails! Sail from island to island, scouting, fighting, looting for treasure, and spending your loot to live out tale worthy adventures.

GOAL
Be the last surviving pirate with the most points and the best adventure to tell.

GAMEPLAY
Players take action using the map deck to expand the board, move, search for resources, place workers, complete adventure cards, and attack each other. As each round ends the AI player increases strength and moves in to attack the nearest player. This forces players to end their turn as far away as possible by either expanding the map or moving. Resources in hand and large boards will result in shorter rounds making it harder as the game progresses. Players not eliminated by the AI or other players win. If both survive the adventures determine the victory.

A competitive skirmish nano card game by Charles Ward.

SUMMARY
Players play on a card size board with 9 spaces. The spaces are not connected equally and some spaces have an advantage when doing a ranged attack. Players move tokens on the board trying to eliminate the opponent's pieces and be as close as possible to their opponent's picnic spot at the end of the game. Players take actions by playing their hand of 8 cards, or both sides of the four cards. The game ends at the end of round 8, or after all cards have been played.

GAMEPLAY
Players choose 1 card from their hand (either the top or bottom half of that card) and simultaneously reveal them. The player with the highest initiative number (in the coin) goes first, and each player either takes 1 of the 2 actions on their card's chosen half or passes. Cards that have been played once are flipped from the silver coin side to the gold coin side and return to the players hand; cards played twice are discarded.

On their turn a player may move 1 or more of their tokens, attack in the same location or a target location, block, hide, taunt, or add 1 reinforcement. Although the actions are resolved in order (highest number card), a block or hide can cancel a certain type of attack as a reaction or preemptively.

The game ends after 8 rounds, when all cards have been discarded. Equidistant tokens are removed after which the player nearest to the opponent's star wins.

Tides of Madness is a sequel to Tides of Time and features gameplay similar to that design. Tides of Time is a drafting game for two players. Each game consists of three rounds in which players draft cards from their hands to build their kingdom. Each card is one of five suits and also has a scoring objective.

After all cards have been drafted for the round, players total their points based on the suits of cards they collected and the scoring objectives on each card, then they record their score. Each round, the players each select one card to leave in their kingdom as a "relic of the past" to help them in later rounds. After three rounds, the player with the the most prosperous kingdom wins.

Tides of Madness adds a new twist to the above game: madness. Some cards, while powerful, harm your psyche, so you must keep an eye on your madness level or else risk losing the game early as your mind is lost to the power of the ancients. More specifically, eight of the eighteen cards in the game feature a madness icon, and while scoring, you receive a madness token for each such icon in your collection of cards. Whoever has the most madness in a round either scores 4 points or discards 1 madness token — and the latter option is valuable because if you ever have nine or more madness, you lose the game immediately.

LOAD is a miniature game of epic clashing action! In LOAD, players take control of mighty group of heroes separated in 2 teams, clashing in head-to-head fights, all in an attempt to wreak enough havoc on their opponent’s base and force them to surrender! Your army ranges from lowly creeps to powerful heroes, each with their own roles to fulfill. It is up to you to use their unique skills and abilities to best your foes on the open field. In LOAD you will coordinate attacks, daringly step through dangerous forest to reach other lanes and assist your heroes, all in attempt to reach opponent’s base and secure victory.

In 30-90 minutes, you will use abilities of your heroes by rolling dice to damage opponents heroes and base.

Heroes are represented by 32mm scale models and Lane creeps by 28mm scale models that are moved around the board to establish tactical dominance.

CREATE your wizard deck from a combination of spell, race & treasure cards.

ADVENTURE board game or RPG-style!

IMPROVE your wizard deck with epic loot and advanced spells.

---

Young Wizards is a card-based tabletop RPG/board game where each player assumes the role of a... Well... A Young Wizard.

Each player constructs a deck of cards representing their spells, equipment and other features (like race). That deck can grow more powerful over time as the player adventures into twisting caverns and dark forests, discovering treasures & gaining experience.

All of that sounds great, and can be done with other tabletop RPGs. How does Young Wizards differ?


     The game can be played without a Game Master(GM)/Dungeon Master for a more "board game" feel.
     If played with a GM, setting up adventures & encounters is a breeze, leaving you more time to focus on your story.
     More schools of magic than you can shake a wand at. Deck-builders rejoice! (of course, we have deck pre-constructions for the wee ones)
     The card-based approach provides the perfect "bridge" between younger players and the deeper world of tabletop RPGs / board games.

Timeline: Cannes & Cinema is a card game played using 55 cards. Each card depicts a Movie on both sides, with the year in which that movie was selected at the Cannes Film Festival occurred on only one side. Players take turns placing a card from their hand in a row on the table. After placing the card, the player reveals the date on it. If the card was placed correctly with the date in chronological order with all other cards on the table, the card stays in place; otherwise the card is removed from play and the player takes another card from the deck.

The first player to get rid of all his cards by placing them correctly wins. If multiple players go out in the same round, then everyone else is eliminated from play and each of those players are dealt one more card for another round of play. If only one player has no cards after a bonus round, he wins; otherwise play continues until a single player goes out.

Timeline: Cannes & Cinema can be combined with any other title in the Timeline series.

Contains 55 cards in French and 55 cards (the same) in English.

Want another way to analyze aspiring politicians and their behavior in dealing with political issues on a daily basis? Try Politricks, a new card game created by two Filipinos in time for the presidential elections. The new card game is drawn from current events and personalities in Philippine politics. The card game consists of 104 deck cards of different stereotypes of "trapos" or traditional politicians, and soap opera events that happened in the Philippines' political timeline through the years.

You and your friends play as a bunch of dirty candidates (called trapos or traditional politicians)trying to win the elections. You can give merienda(bribe)or low blow your rivals. Do whatever it takes to collect the most votes and rule the country.

May the worst person win!

"My code name is Chronos, and now you are my Agents. The threads of the time have been torn and mysterious artifacts suddenly appeared in the world. The most dangerous areas of the metropolis are in turmoil. The Chronomancer is destroying the Reality, it is your task to defeat her!"

A team of fighters and experts is looking for OOPART - Out Of Place ARTifacts, and is ready to clash with the worst criminals of the Planet. That group of agents has dared defy the Chronomancer to restore the Reality and Time's order".

Chronomancer is a cooperative board game, for 2-6 players with a 1-3 hrs/game duration, set in metropolitan areas in hot-spot countries all around the world. Each player controls an Agent of the Chrono Team and has to complete the Mission of the game by recovering weapons, valuables and ancient artifacts. Moving through a scenario that simulates a dangerous city, Agents will fight against mercenaries, evil bosses, powerful creatures that came from the past, and sometimes with the Chronomancer too.

Different kinds of action are available for each Agent, such as melee, fire-arm attacks, technological tools and bombing raids.

The main feature of Chronomancer is the modular design of the board that allows creating countless environments and collision situations, offering a new game experience at every time.

Depending on the missions and on the related objective to be achieved, Chronomancer also suggests a multiple level game structure and an evolving plot. All the Agents get involved in the main quest that must be completed for the final Victory. Each Agent can earn honor points during the fulfillment of the mission, but will also have his/her own agenda of personal goals to be reached. If the main quest has been resolved, the Agent with the greater amount of honor points wins over everyone. Moreover, by following the numerical order of the main missions (Mission 1, Mission 2, etc.), you will discover the Chronomacer's plans, living a long adventure game by game. But you can also pick missions at random and play them on their own, with different sets and enemies every time.

A modular board, 10 mission, 8 characters, 4 bosses an several time themed creature and characters from the past grant an always new gaming experience and great longevity.

From the publisher:

"Seguindo a descrição da testemunha, a polícia faz um retrato falado. Com base nele, o detetive detém os suspeitos para averiguações e tenta prender o culpado. Não é interessante? Em RETRATO FALADO isto é ainda mais, já que às vezes você é o detetive, outras a testemunha e até o desenhista da polícia. Não é um desafio?"

Or, in a free translation:

"Following the description of the witness, the police makes a police sketch. Based on it, the detective holds the suspects for questioning and attempts to arrest the culprit. Isn't it interesting? In RETRATO FALADO this is even more, since you are sometimes the detective, other times you are the witness and even the police artist. Isn't it a challenge?"

In Retrato Falado, a cooperative game for only three people, one person - the witness - will try to memorize some cards with faces drawings and then make a police sketch of one randomly selected card (without seeing). A second player - the police artist - will "draw" the face described using the tiles representing eyes, nose, mouth, etc. Finally, the third player - the detective - will try to find out what was the card that the witness described. If he chooses correctly, everyone scores.

In MiniSkull Caverns, 1-3 heroes will compete to explore the caverns beneath the ruins of MiniSkull Castle and return with riches beyond their wildest dreams.  You are one of those optimistic explorers.  Are you prepared to risk your life for diamonds the size of a wild boar?  Along the way you will encounter monsters, battle other heroes, and recover some priceless gems.  Be careful though, the more noise you make, the more you will attract the deadly denizens of MiniSkull Caverns.  Before you can escape with your spoils you must battle the affectionately, though unsuitably, named Tiny.  Dragons don’t like it when you try to burgle their baubles.

Object: The object of MiniSkull Caverns is to guide your hero through the maze of caverns, managing your strength, and battling monsters  and other heroes, all while searching for priceless Gems.  Once you have acquired two of these Gems you must return to the center space on the map and battle Tiny in order to escape.

2 Player Variant: When playing with two players you must defeat Tiny and escape with three gems instead of two.

Solo Variant: Collect all four gems and escape before time runs out.

Mechanics: The mechanics use a combination of action selection using a rotating action card and player selection control card, similar to what is in Empire Engine, along with straight up dice combat against monsters and PvP dice combat with strategic modifiers the players 
choose.

Across eight turns, you will live out your life in a city somewhere in the world.

Each turn represents a phase in one’s life:

1. Starting Out
    2. Meeting that special someone
    3. Settling down with that special someone
    4. Kids arrive (by birth, adoption or otherwise)
    5. Kids grow up to be teenagers
    6. Kids leave home, the nest is empty
    7. Getting old
    8. Approaching this life’s end

The game is played on a five by five tile 'city' - with 13 fixed tiles (representing CBD, four inner suburbs, four outer suburbs and four corner 'holiday home' locations) and 12 Modifiable (Mod) tiles which represent different landmarks (for example restaurant, art gallery, rubbish dump etc).

Each Mod tile has a scoring value each turn, which can change depending on the turn (phase of life) you are in. For example living near a retirement home scores well in later rounds.

You start the game with a house in an inner suburb. Players draft a hand of 'mod' tiles which allow them to modify the landmarks on the board (for example turn a park into a 'fancy' park, which scores more highly) - they also receive one temporary closure tile (means a tile is not scored for the current round) and one demolition tile (which permanently removes a Mod tile and replaces it with one from the side of the board).

Your objective is to optimise where you live in relation to your particular stage in life, and this is scored at the end of each turn.

Each turn you either:
1. Move house
2. Buy a holiday home (allowing you to place a second home on a corner of the board and then score the adjacent tiles each turn) - you may only perform this action once per game, or
3. Modify a Mod tile

You cannot pass in Living.

Each turn you then score the tiles orthogonally adjacent to your home and your holiday home (if you have one).

At the end of the eighth turn, the highest score wins the game!

Rock On! The Geology Game of Brains & Sheer Determination

Spark or expand kids' interest in Rocks, Geology and our magnificent Earth via the EXPANDED VERSION of this teacher-recommended, fun, learning game.

Now includes 5 levels of play offering fun, challenge and education for the pre-reader through elementary school age.

This American-Made product includes 60+ polished Rocks & Minerals and a 15-Specimen Rock & Mineral Collection any kid would be proud to own.

Player Cards for up to 6 players along with a Master Rock Guide and 18 Rock Call Cards chocked full of educational & fun facts.

How to play:
Rock Hound Level - 
Players take turns drawing a call card from the pile.  If the rock on the call card matches a rock on the player cards, place any random one of the 60+ rock marker chips on top of the picture on the player cards.

Winning: The first player to cover all the rocks on their player card wins by saying "Rock On!"

Pink, Green, Purple and Orange Levels -
Choose to play 1 of the 4 pick axe levels on the call cards.  Each level is played the same way: The 1st player draws a card from the call card pile. Without revealing the card, they read the name of the rock.  Anyone who has that rock on their player card, places a random marker chip on top of the picture on their player card.  Also match and place the rock specimen on its picture on the master rock guide.  Next, the player who drew the call card asks the player to their left a question from the correct level of play.  If they answer correctly, they place a marker chip on one of the "Rocky" the Geologist squares on their player card.  If answered incorrectly, continuing clockwise around the table, players take turns trying to correctly answer the question.  Of a "Rock my world" card is drawn and the question is answered correctly, 2 "Rocky" squares may be covered on the player card.

Winning: The first player to cover all the squares on their player card wins.  Or, After all call cards have been drawn, the winner is the player with the most squares covered on their player card.
Monikers: Something Something is the second expansion for Monikers. It features 112 new names to add more variety to the base game! It can also be played as a standalone game.

War of the Races is a fast-paced card game that is fun, easy to learn and extremely strategic.

5 armies - Orcs, Humans, Elves, Dwarves and Demons - fight for supremacy in the ancient kingdom of Erathmor. Command your armies, send out troops, utilize heroes, sorcerers and more to eliminate opposing armies and leave your mark in history with the War of the Races.

Each race is sold as a separate deck of cards, each with unique abilities and advantages. Players send out infantry to attack opposing armies or the King, who start with 50 and 5 health, respectively. The infantry consist of soldiers, archers, rogues, guards and fighters. These cards can be enhanced with special spells. In addition, a guard can be used to prevent that card from being easily defended against. Next, players send out their sorcerers, who utilize water, earth and fire spells to attack the opposing armies. Other players must counter with other sorcerers, creating a simple but effective 'rock, paper, scissors' effect! Lastly, heroes are sent the field, each with unique abilities, such as healing the army, reflecting any opposing attack back to the dealer, calling for reinforcements and more. Strategy cards are also used to take opposing soldiers as enemies, revive your King, and more.

The last army to remain wins the War of the Races!

Little Storm Thinks is a children's game. The players are each given one wooden stick of each colour. Then one by one they roll a die with different colours on the sides, and got to take a wooden stick of that colour they get on the die. Each player also have a card (thought card) with a figure on, and have to make their figure on the card with there wooden sticks. After the dice roll a player can place as many sticks on the card that is possible. There are three versions to play the game. The easy game is played with the white thought cards. A figure is complete when the wooden sticks are in the correct places (as shown on the thought card). The difficult game is played with the coloured thought cards. A figure is not complete unless the wooden sticks are in the same colours and in the correct places as shown on the thought card. There is also a cooperative game version.

Tragedy has struck the prestigious girls' prep school. Psychic radiation emanating from unspeakable abominations has awakened a dark phenomenon: the girls' emotions have become manifest, taking on terrifying forms. Staff and students have vanished, leaving behind only whispers of horror.

Trinity, the head girl, now a patient at the maximum-security wing of Darkwood Asylum, revealed a chilling truth: the girls' imaginations have become reality. Her words echo through the asylum's corridors: "The things we imagined came to life..."

In Trinity's Challenge, you'll experience the chaos of midterm exams, where emotions run high and psychic energies clash. You'll fight for survival, unconsciously unleashing your frustration and anger upon your opponents. The madness will only subside when your targets are eliminated.

Roll the dice to accumulate psychic energy, then unleash devastating waves to shatter your opponents' minds and bodies. But beware: a single misstep will trigger a crippling backlash, inflicting a debilitating headache that will leave you reeling.

Calm before the Little Storm is a children's card game of motion, concentration and memory. Each turn first begin with a part of concentration, and when the storm comes and it's time for the activity. In the calm before the storm, participants must remember the cards they draw, until they pull a Storm card, then it would be time for the activities drawn. For each motion remembered from the cards, the player can keep the card. The player in the end of the game with the most cards is the winner.

The door creaks open, its hinges wailing in protest. Jane's voice trembles as she asks, "What are you doing?!" You reply, your voice laced with a mix of excitement and trepidation, "This decrepit mansion could hold secrets...and treasures. We'd be fools to ignore it." Your companions nod in agreement, their eyes gleaming with a mix of curiosity and fear.

As you ascend to the attic, the air grows thick with the stench of decay. You begin to rummage through the dusty relics, but your search is abruptly interrupted by the door slamming shut. Jane's scream pierces the air, and she stumbles toward the door, her finger quivering as she points to the opposite corner.

You follow her gaze, and your heart freezes. A figure stumbles toward you, its movements jerky and unnatural. A z-zombie, its eyes vacant, its skin gray and decaying, it shambles closer. Your companions cluster around Jane, their faces etched with terror, as they realize the door won't budge...it's locked, trapping you with the unnatural creature.

You and your companions are trapped in a desperate bid for survival. To escape the zombie-infested mansion, you'll need to crack the combination locks on each door, room by room. Your fate will be decided by the roll of the dice, as you strive to achieve the crucial goals that will secure your escape.

The stakes are dire: failure will condemn you to a gruesome demise, with the zombie feasting on your flesh. The horrific consequence of defeat is that you'll rise again, joining the undead hordes as a mindless, flesh-eating monster.

Will you and your companions successfully navigate the treacherous mansion, overcoming the zombie threat and emerging alive? The dice will decide.

WH1CH GAM3, a.k.a. W3LCH35 5P13L, is a small card game that can be used to determine which game your group should play next.

Each person chooses one game they wish to play, with the player who finished last in the previous game (or the host) choosing a second game. Place all of these games on the table. Each person draws a card at random, face down. The person with the lowest numbered card removes a game, then the person with the next lowest card removes a game, etc., until only one game remains on the table. Now it's time to play!

Multiple versions of WH1CH GAM3 have been published, all of which play the same and all of which have different sets of numbers in them. Shuffle one or more sets together to determine what to play when you have more than eight players on hand...

From the publisher's website:

Noisy Person Cards is a party game designed to help you develop new character voices.

Using card matching mechanics inspired by games like Apples to Apples and Utter Nonsense, NPC challenges you to lend a voice to potential thousands of character combinations.

NPC is best when played with 3 or more people. Games can last from 10 minutes, to 2 hours, depending on how long you want to play. The print and play set is ok for folks aged 15+, and becomes ok for all ages when you remove the cards marked with a lil’ skull icon.

Players take turns speaking a selected phrase in the voice of a character chosen by the round's judge, who then decides who performed the best voice for the round. Both the judge and the speakers have ways to attach additional descriptors to the current character, Upping the Ante of difficulty, hilarity, and reward for the round.

Totenstadt is a hack & slay card game that takes the zombie apocalypse into a German city setting!

Totenstadt allows you take control of many different mercenaries like a firefighter, biker, priest, soldier, hitman, doctor, scientists and more — each with their own set of abilities — to defeat the gruesome hordes and fight for the survival of mankind!
But beware because zombies are not the only problems you have to face in the dark streets as crazy people and even mutants will stand in your way!

On your way through the city, you will make some friends, too. Soldiers, adventurers, merchants and more will help you to fulfill your mission, grant you helping abilities, or give you equipment. It's all fun and games until you run into one of the events and all hell breaks loose!
Are you ready to clean up the town and find out what really goes on behind the scenes?

2016 marked the 140th anniversary of the Little Bighorn Campaign. This struggle has been depicted in numerous conflict simulation games; it is certainly one of the most fascinating subjects in the wargame hobby. One-Minute Little Bighorn is a microgame attempting to portray the battle with a small map and a limited number of counters.

One-Minute Little Bighorn is a solitaire challenge. The entire battle can be fought in a minute or two. However, the game offers a player most of the tactical choices available to Custer in 1876.

The player represents the commander of the 7th Cavalry and army units represent battalions containing several companies. Tribal warriors like Crazy Horse are included in the groups of Native American fighting men swarming out of the village to block the advance of the cavalry. Historical factors like the escape of tribal noncombatants and the arrival of Benteen are contained in the rules. Victory is determined by the level of success achieved by Custer... if he survives the battle.

This companion game to the previously released One-Minute Bulge is a free Print & Play game with a single 8.5" x 11" map, charts, rules, and two dozen playing pieces or markers.

The Holzbox edition was limited to 500 copies.  It contained E1/E2 Company Track which was a mini-expansion that was exclusive to this limited edition and was never released by itself.

Company E1 allows investing players to interact with discarded card.
Company E2 allows investing players to permanently have diamond merchants and bonus mining icons for the company.


In Mombasa, players acquire shares of chartered companies based in Mombasa, Cape Town, Saint-Louis, and Cairo and propagate trading posts of these companies throughout the African continent in order to earn the most money.

Mombasa features a unique, rotating-display hand-mechanism that drives game play. Each round players choose action cards from their hand, then reveal them simultaneously and carry out the actions. These cards are then placed in a discard pile, and the previously played cards recovered for the subsequent round.

Each company has a double-sided company track, so games will vary quite a lot based on which tracks are revealed and at which companies they are placed.

Description from the publisher:

Papà Paolo brings you to the beautiful city of Naples, birthplace of one of the world's favorite dishes: pizza.

In Papà Paolo, 2 to 4 players compete to deliver the most pizzas to the hungry customers of Naples. To do this, you must outsmart your rivals by being a clever investor, bidding on the right city tiles, and creating your own little district of Naples.

Over the course of five game rounds, players first have to plan their actions carefully, choosing whether they want to invest in new pizzerias, make express deliveries, get sponsored by the bank, or decide to expand their district. Once all players have used up their action tokens, players get rewarded by receiving Lira, which they can then use in a bidding phase to determine how many deliveries you can make, and how many pizzas you can deliver. Once you deliver pizzas to your hungry customers, they reward you by boosting your abilities, making each action more powerful as the game progresses. Every decision counts, but Papà Paolo is a very accessible game, which will charm players of all ages alike.

Each player has 16 playing pieces: 7 hunters, 4 catchers, 2 scouts, 2 squires and 1 bux-master. The goal of the game is to capture the opponent bux-master. The hunters move up to 2 spaces, the catchers up to 3 spaces, the scout up to 4 spaces, the bux-master and his squires 1 space (no jumping over other pieces allowed). If pieces of both payers are on three connected spaces in a straight line, the minority piece is eliminated from play unless it is able to escape in the next turn.

There are rules for 2 variants included:

Buxelkuh: One cow has to break through a line of 9 peasants and 1 mayor. The latter try to trap the cow.

Buxtehu: The players try to get all 16 playing pieces to the opposite end of the game board. Each time a player gets one of his pieces to a space at the other end of the board, he may take one or more enemy pieces off the board. The game ends if all 11 spaces at one end of the board are occupied or if there ar no more pieces on the board. The player with the most captured pieces wins the game.

First volume of Infantry Assault

Infantry Assault is a skirmish game between 2-4 players on various fields of battle. The objectives are varied and include a campaign which can be separated into several scenarios if you wish.

The major asset of Infantry Assault is to provide a fluid game system with ease of access, to share the fun of miniature games with family and friends, and for people outside of the hobby to discover the pleasure of the game. The simplicity of the game is thanks to a unique and ingenious system, this will keep the tactical advantage of this type of game, implementing a storyline. In campaign mode, the winner will be the player who gains the more points at the end but there is no obligation to play each scenario in an orderly manner.

In Platoon Command you take the role of a platoon leader, guiding your platoon into combat in order to capture critical battlefield objectives. Platoon Command is a quick-playing game that uses cards for combat, command and control, fog of war, and attrition. The mission objective is to gain Objective Points by controlling areas of the battlefield. You accomplish this objective by issuing orders to your command group, three rifle squads, and specialized personnel.

In this survival co-op, you and your crewmates find yourselves in the middle of an ocean on an alien world after a mishap during interstellar travel.

In 30 days a planet-wide storm will knock out all communications. You need to find three islands and repair the rescue beacons that were launched when your spacecraft was destroyed.

During your exploration you are as likely to find unwelcoming creatures as helpful items.

Decide how to use your stats, abilities, and dice allocation to face these challenges, and the challenge of propelling your watercraft through this ocean, and activate the distress signal. Otherwise, you will likely suffer the fate of this planet's previous inhabitants.

Nécropole is a boardgame designed for 2 to 6 players, and can be played in several mode (teams, competitive or versus a game master).

Each player take control of up to 3 undead heroes. They can be vampires, necromancers or ghosts.
Each hero is chosen amongst three classes: sorcerer â˜…, warrior âŒ½ or assassin â˜¾.

Classes will have great impact within attack phases during fights. They will give your heroes dedicated abilities (all unique).

âŒ½ Warriors master "talent" to dominate the battlefield.
â˜… Sorcerers are spell casters, specialized in control and area effect damages.
â˜¾ Assassins use their skills to make surgical strikes against their preys.

Abilities and legendary artifacts are won by exploring the various Necropole's districts and accomplishing epic quests.
You can also attack your opponents and go into the slummy areas to trade souls for gear.

Possibilities are endless to fulfill your objectives and win the game.

As each card is unique, each game is unique too.

Now is your turn to master the Necropole, city of the dead.

Necropole is an epic game of exploration and skirmish fights.
Players will battle against other undeads (controlled by theor opponents or the game master), using cards in their hands and rolling dice.

In this new game you travel the world with your own fleet of cointainerships and manage large seaports. You want to be the biggest but there are many dangers in the way: storm, clashes, pirats,... You are in direct conflict with other shipowners, these are your competitors.

A smart strategy, making decissions fast, choosing the best routes, buying new ships and seaports, buying-out another shipowner, reacting on a crisis ... A nose for business and a dose of luck will determine if your fleet will win this game.

Sea Giants is a game for 2 to 4 players, you roll dice and move your ships forward on the course they are traveling, you get money if you end on a harbour spot and have the opportunity to buy the harbour, if no one else owns it yet. You can also spend your turn buying new ships for different courses. The game can end either by setting a time limit or by buying all harbours from other players so you are the monopolist.

Have a nice course !

In the dark tunnels and caves far below the surface of our world, evil creatures lurk in the shadows.
Some of them, such as the cunning dark elves, have developed a civilization – and in every successful civilization games are played, so the masterminds can sharpen their wits, while the lower townsmen have their share of distraction.

Arachne is such a game: While you can find some elements of the chess game played by the surface dwellers, there are quite a lot of differences, too:
First of all, as a devotion to the Spider Goddess, Arachne is played on the strands of a spider web. Also, the cruel and traitorous nature of the dark elves is reflected in Arachne, too: Aside from being able to capture his own playing pieces, each turn, a player gets the option to move and to capture with an opposing playing piece.
So, whatever you plan; always be aware, that the true enemy strikes from within!

The game has been created during the 2016 One Page PNP Contest.

The Story
You’ve finally found a place to call home! There’s a safe space for the nest and plenty of cheese lying around. There are just two problems, you aren’t the only mouse here and, worse yet, a bunch of cats are roaming about. But it’s dinnertime and nothing’s going to stop you from getting that cheese!

Objective
Be crafty, strategic, and fast! You’ll need to split your time between progress and sabotage as you and the other mice race to be the first to return TWO cheeses to the nest.

The thief starts at the hotel and tries to reach the train station to win the game. The 6 kid detectives start at various spaces on the board and have to try to trap the thief so that he can't move. The kid detective who makes the last move to trap the thief wins the game. Movement is one space per turn.

Another version is called "Achtung! Feind hört mit", where the hunted game piece is a spy.

Blade and Brush is a simple yet intellectual game of shared storytelling through the medium of haiku.

Players take on the roles of unique, self-defined characters such as wandering monks, plucky adventurers, and questing warriors. Throughout the game, as the characters journey, they encounter a series of dilemmas. Using poems to solve problems, help people, and get into trouble, the players must collaborate and compete to weave the most entertaining story. The game can be played at a family gathering with children and grandparents over cups of warm tea, or at a late night gathering of close friends with a bottle of warm sake.

Arm your Time Travelers and duel for control over the Timeline. Stack the deck, bluff your foes, orchestrate your strategy, and take your chances as you take command in the TIME WARS.

Gather a Strike Team of Time Travelers. Arm them with high-tech weapons and tools. Duel for control over the lives and events in the Timeline. Achieve your Goals… or foil those of your foes. Bluff your opponents, and bide your time, waiting for the right moment to strike, and collapse the Timeline. As one version of the past crumbles into oblivion, another will rise in its place. The battlefield is history. The stakes the future. Which future will you fight for?

In Time Wars: Supreme Command, you will become the Supreme Commander of your own Time Corps. Assembling your Strike Team allows you to dictate the flow of history, so that it meets your Goals, or thwarts the attempts of your foe. Time is your only currency. Each turn, your one choice will make or break your strategy.

As the world’s first Deck Stacking Game, there are no discard piles in this card game. Instead, when something is discarded, you decide whether it goes on the bottom of your deck, or your opponent’s. Streamline your strategy by removing cards from your deck that you can’t use. But be careful, as everything you give up could be used against you.

Engage your opponents in deep strategy over and over again with a game that only takes minutes to learn and play. Two players can play right out of the box. With each additional Core Set, you can add another two players to the experience in team battles.

HexGo is played on a hexagon tiled by equilateral triangles.(see picture below) A corner of one of these triangles is called a "house". A side of one of these triangles is called a "street".

During the game, stones are placed on houses. Player-I places black stones, while player-II places white stones. The opening move should be decided by "swapping": one person decides where the opening move will go, and then his opponent chooses whether to make the opening move or not.

Linking Families

A "family" is a group of stones of the same color, such that you can travel along streets between any two stones in the group, without visiting an unoccupied house or an enemy stone.
Label the six sides of the hexagonal board as A, B, C, D, E, and F, in the clockwise order in which they appear, and group them in the following three pairs: A with B, C with D, E with F.

A family "links" one of these pairs, say A and B, if members of that family occupy a house on side A as well as a house on side B. Any houses inside the region surrounded by side A, side B, and a family linking A and B are "dominated" by that family.

Forbidden Moves

You may not place a stone on a house if it would be impossible to add more stones to the board to make the first stone part of a family linking one of the three pairs of sides, without removing some enemy stones. Also, you may not place a stone in any region dominated by an enemy family.

Capturing

If you make a move which blocks some enemy stones from linking any of the three pairs of sides, then those enemy stones are removed from the board. If you make a move which links any of the three pairs of sides, then any enemy stones in houses which are now dominated by some of your families are removed from the board.

End Game

"Territory" is defined this way: Each house occupied by one of your stones is included in your territory. An unoccupied house is included in your territory if it is not possible to travel along streets from that house to some enemy stone without first visiting one of your own stones. 
Eventually, each player can only place stones within his own territory. Then the game is over. The winner is the player whose territory includes the most houses.

That's all!

HexGo was inspired by the classic games Hex, Go, Tanbo, and Star.

Helionox: Mercury Protocol is the first stand-alone expansion to Helionox: The Last Sunset. It contains a new set of cards, new planets, and ships that integrate with a pick up and delivery system. Combining it with the original game allows for a 4-player game.

From the rules:
"Identity Pursuit is a game that uses the concept of archetypes to challenge you and your fellow players to look more closely at how you see yourselves and each other."

Each player begins by placing a pawn on the starting square and drawing four cards, each of which names and describes and archetype such as "mother" or "adventurer."  Three cards are kept and the fourth, which the player least identifies with, is placed face-up in front of the player.

In turn, each player either chooses a card from his/her hand or one of the face-up cards from another player and finds the corresponding question with multiple choice answers in a booklet.  The player reads the question without comment and then chooses his or her answer and records it secret with the "players choice wheel."  The other players may then discuss the question and then provide their answers to the question.  Finally, the current player reads the definition of the archetype and the "correct" answer (i.e. the one that corresponds best to the archetype).  The current player then moves his or her pawn on the track a number or spaces depending on how well his/her answer matches the other players' answers.

After playing a card from his/her hand, the current player then draws another card.

The first player to reach the end of the track wins.

Fayre of the Forgotten plays on an abandoned funfair around 1900.

The tragedy began when a new mirror arrived for the main attraction of the fayre - the Hall of Mirrors. The mirror was rumored to be a powerful magical artifact. But instead of granting wishes and riches, it shattered souls the instant someone glimpsed his or her reflection in it. No visitors come to the fayre anymore as it is a soulless place - and each of the seven proprietors also wants to leave, but as everyone of them has looked into the mirror, their souls are broken. They need to recover their ...or at least a ... complete soul before they can leave. To collect all 20 soul shards the players visit fayre attractions, play action cards, and take control of the attractions. However, there are more aggressive ways to acquire soul shards, as there are ways to just trade your soul shards with an opponent, whether he likes it or not. But beware: exchanging a soul is likely to drive you insane.

The Fayre is designed for two players, where it has a nice tactical level. But it is also fun for up to 5 players, where gambling and the ability to react to the present situation become more important. A soul exchange at the right moment can win or lose the game.

Nebil Abdulgadir, known from big computer game successes like Crysis as well as for his oil paintings in the art scene, is responsible for the great artwork in this game.

Overview
Eastern Blades is the samurai card dueling game we have all been waiting for. Players will adopt one style of the characters dealt to them at the beginning of the game. Then all players will battle for supremacy using their character to defeat all comers. Game play is designed to depict extremely faced paced sword duels on the battlefield. 2-5 players will take part using only the core game. Games last 10 to 15 minutes. Expansions are planned to begin in early 2017.

Game Play
 After selecting their character players get  ready for the coming onslaught by selecting stances, choosing an attack or item and finalizing their plan of attack. However, we all know that on the battlefield even the best laid plans do not survive contact with the enemy. Players will simultaneously select their actions and who they will attack each round. Upon being attacked combatants will be able to parry or even redirect the attack just like in a true sword fight. This “ebb and flow” of combat will persist as long as it takes to declare a winner. This is no easy task as every decision will devastate either your enemy or yourself. You will inevitably find yourself asking questions like what stance I  need to be in next, should I block or should I hold for a bigger attack, is the opponent faking their threat level, and can I get my attack off before theirs? In any event this high stakes sword fight will have you coming back again and again.

How do we know you will like it?
BC Games focuses on making quality games over a quantity of games. For this game we consulted Marty Katz Shihan, Shichidan (7th Dan in Bushido), founder of Bushido Karate Dojo in an effort to add a large shot of realism to the flow of the game. We even had the maneuvers translated into Japanese (with subtitles) and cross referenced them so some of the maneuvers block and counter others specifically like they do in the real world. You will enjoy this game for its realism and attention to detail regarding the art of Bushido and the way of the warrior. The Samurai put all they had into their training and ability as an honorable but lethal force at the altar of war. Now you can live out your dream of an amazing duel of your own.

Well, it was bound to happen sooner or later; and now the zombie apocalypse is here. But never fear humanity, heroes have emerged to save us all! Ninjas, robots, pirates, monkeys, and aliens are here to defeat the zombie hordes and restore order. All they need is a little bit of your help.

Zombie Farkle is a press-your-luck dice rolling game that is fun for the entire family. Each game consist of 6 custom etched and color filled dice in a custom printed dice bag so you can take it with you anywhere.

The object of the game is to destroy as many zombies as possible by rolling combinations of dice. You can score the points you earn, or push your luck further for a greater payout. But remember, if you get too reckless, the zombies will eat your brains.

Torii is a skirmish wargame set on Feudal Japan, created by Miniatures and Wargames to use Zenit Miniatures’ range of miniatures (specifically Kensei’s)
In Torii you’ll have to lead a group of about 8-12 warriors that will have work together to accomplish their clan objectives.

Every game is different. Scenery, main and secondary missions will change, so you’ll never get bored of playing Torii.

Torii is quick to learn, with great tactical and strategic depth, with a duration of about 45-60 minutes.

Torii is a skirmish wargame set on Feudal Japan, created by Miniatures and Wargames to use Zenit Miniatures’ range of miniatures (specifically Kensei’s)
In Torii you’ll have to lead a group of about 8-12 warriors that will have work together to accomplish their clan objectives.

Every game is different. Scenery, main and secondary missions will change, so you’ll never get bored of playing Torii.

Torii is quick to learn, with great tactical and strategic depth, with a duration of about 45-60 minutes.

18Ireland is a member of the 18xx family of games, set in Ireland.

From the rule book:
18Ireland represents a rather different take on the 18xx system. Ireland was a poor country, but there is no lack of enthusiasm for railways among investors. Up to 13 5-share companies will start in a random sequence. Some of these companies will become successful, others, as a result of underinvestment, isolation or poor timing will struggle to survive. All is not lost for the strugglers, however. A unique shareholder voting mechanism allows companies to merge into 10-share companies(sometimes against their director’s wishes) with their more or less successful neighbours.
Track laying provides its own problems as many track tiles are unique. Often, there is no available tile to provide the most efficient route so a roundabout route sometimes must suffice. There are two types of track that can be built: broad gauge and narrow gauge. There are no purchasable narrow gauge locomotives; instead narrow gauge track operates in an abstract way and boosts the value of the broad gauge stations to which it connects.  
Trains in 18Ireland are hex trains. They become obsolete in two stages: rusted trains may be bought back from the bank at half price (but also half capability) and continue to operate until they rot and are then removed. As the game progresses the train rush becomes brutal. Player bankruptcy does not end the game and survivors continue until they have broken a bank that starts with just £4,000.
18Ireland can be played by 3 to 6 players. Experience has shown that at a low player count, this is a “run good companies” game. At a higher player count, the game is more combative as share portfolios are more diverse and the hostile merger becomes a bigger factor in the game. By choosing the player count, players can select the style of 18xx game that they prefer.

Aim of the game: to be the last to play a stick.

Game of strategy: should you play the sticks vertically or horizontally? Should you use your own sticks or those of your opponent?  Taking the risk that they will be used up; should you   play them?
Game of observation: which sticks are holding up which others ? You need a good sense of three dimensions.

The game's being funded now on Kickstarter: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/117402901/street-rod-build-and-race-your-own-hot-rod-with-ea

It's the summer of 1963 and it's time to race some hot rods. With the few bucks you have you buy yourself a simple car. By racing against other drivers you win some bucks, buy parts, and customize your car -- until you're good enough to race 'The King.'

Street Rod: the card game is based on the Street Rod video game series launched in 1989.

Each round, a player may choose one of the following actions: buy cars or car parts, race opponents from the deck, or race other players.

By buying cars or parts, a player improves the cards in his hand. The hand cards are used when racing against opponents (in the form of car cards) or other players.

When racing, first you pick the track to race on (drag race, Mulholland Drive, or Aqueduct Race). Next, determine your score on the chosen track based on the cards in your hand. The player with the highest score has the best chance to win -- but luck factors into the equation. Draw the next card from the deck and check the Bad Luck number to see whether you won the race or not.

The player who beats The King, the best opponent in the deck, wins the game!

You're the new owner of a small campground along the river Ardèche. It all seems so easy! A small plot of land, a reception and a website is all you need to receive some income from tourists. 
Satisfied you take a rest – but not for long, as your guests already leave for greener pastures! They like your competitor's campground more: the ‘Clash d’Ardèche’ has begun.

Claim the best sites, bluff out your competitors, bribe the mayor and fulfill your secret assignment to win!

In 'Clash d'Ardèche', 1-4 players compete with each other by trying to build the campground of their (secret) assignment. They do this by buying sites, swimming pool / disco / hostel etc. and Publicity. And, of course, by pricing their opponents out of the market. Guests will typically leave the worst campground for the best one. Also the mayor is giving favors to the ones he likes, so do not forget to bribe him!

Gameplay is about 20 minutes / player.
